channel.title: OnOptions
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: What Kate McKinnon’s multi-hyphenate career can teach us about creativity
item.description: For many stars, writing a children’s book is a fun side project they do to capitalize on their fame. Kate McKinnon—a Saturday Night Live alum who has ...

item.title: Sleep Tracking Is Just Making You More Anxious. Here’s What Science Says You Should Do Instead
item.description: Apple new Sleep Score is the latest in a growing trend that isn’t necessarily making us more rested.

item.title: Anthropic and IBM Are Teaming Up to Build an AI-Powered Coding Tool
item.description: Microsoft and Deloitte also recently partnered with Anthropic on similar AI tools for enterprises.

item.title: Meet the Gen-Z Founder Building the Canva of Memes
item.description: Getting attention online has never been harder. Jason Levin’s Memelord Technologies has an answer: sell memes-as-a-service.

item.title: This fancy portable mattress is the only way you’ll get me to camp
item.description: Camping. Why anyone would put themselves through an odyssey of gross insects and pooping in holes is beyond me, but you do you, Steve. I’ll do me. How...

item.title: Gen Z killed cursive, so Docusign gave us a new way to sign our names
item.description: Libbie Bischoff didn’t set out to reinvent the signature. Really, she was just flipping through a vintage knitting magazine from the 1950s. The Minnea...

item.title: Jamie Dimon isn’t taking a recession off the table for 2026: ‘You don’t wish it because certain people will get hurt’
item.description: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon says a U.S. recession could hit in 2026, a warning to markets not to get complacent despite strong GDP growth and AI optimism

item.title: OpenAI dreams of Apple
item.description: OpenAI’s DevDay, held Monday at San Francisco’s historic Fort Mason, was exceptionally Apple-coded.

item.title: Gold’s price record is driven by the ‘debasement trade,’ China, and fear of an AI bubble, analysts say
item.description: Gold surged over $4,000/oz, up 50% this year, driven by investor fears over government debt, a weaker dollar, a buying spree by China’s central bank, ...

item.title: 5 signs that you’re working with under-performers (and they know it)
item.description: Move over quiet quitting , bare minimum Mondays, and career cushioning. A new workplace behavior is on the rise: the self-aware underperformer. Contra...

item.title: The White House Keeps Crowning Stock Market Winners
item.description: The U.S. took a 10 percent stake in Trilogy Metals and the stock soared over 200 percent.

item.title: How to Unlock Innovation With the Kaizen and Kaikaku Methods
item.description: Growth companies that master both continuous improvement and breakthrough innovation outpace those that only optimize.

item.title: Multimillionaire serial entrepreneur cried the first time she made ‘real money’—but not in a good way: ‘Wealth doesn’t erase your problems. It magnifies them’
item.description: Emily Lyons said commas in her bank account didn’t help her feel relieved, but rather scared of losing all she had gained.

item.title: Attention companies: Job seekers may have more power than you think
item.description: Today’s labor market may be stagnating, but it’s also uncertain . Candidates aren’t behaving as many leaders would expect. The dynamic is trending tow...

item.title: ‘Big Short’ investor Steve Eisman warns the U.S. economy is a ‘tale of two cities’ that ‘is not even growing 50 basis points outside of AI’
item.description: Eisman said if you erase AI infrastructure spending from projected U.S. GDP growth for 2025, the economic picture exposes a struggling consumer.

item.title: Greece is back to being a developed market. Its stocks have surged this year.
